title: John Hart Evans
text:
John 'Jack' Hart Evans (9 April 1881 – 9 August 1959) was a <a href="Wales">Welsh</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> centre who played club rugby for <a href="Pontypool%20RFC">Pontypool</a>. He won three caps for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> during 1907.
Rugby career.
Evans came to note as a rugby player when he turned out for Pontypool Thursday, a minor town team. He soon progressed to Pontypool RFC, who were at the time making a notable appearance at club level and gaining caps internationally. In 1906, Evans was one of five Pontypool players to be selected to face <a href="Paul%20Roos%20%28rugby%20player%29">Paul Roos</a>' <a href="1906-07%20South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20tour">1906 touring South African team</a> as part of the <a href="Monmouthshire%20County%20RFC">Monmouthshire</a> team. Evans was partnered at centre for the Monmouthshire game with Pontypool teammate <a href="Jack%20Jones%20%28rugby%20player%29">Jack Jones</a>, but Evans spent much of the game in defensive cover and he and Jones were deemed out of form against the much faster Springboks. The game ended in a 17-0 defeat for Monmouthshire.
Just a few months after the South Africa game, Evans won his first international cap for Wales when he was brought in as centre for the opening game of the <a href="1907%20Home%20Nations%20Championship">1907 Home Nations Championship</a>. Partnered with <a href="Rhys%20Gabe">Rhys Gabe</a>, Evans was given the difficult task of replacing <a href="Gwyn%20Nicholls">Gwyn Nicholls</a> one of the most inventive and loved centres in Welsh rugby history. The 1907 campaign started well, with a convincing win over England, and the Welsh selectors responded by keeping faith with Evans for the next two games of the tournament. Wales suffered a narrow loss to Scotland, but responded with a large victory over Ireland. Despite playing in a successful Championship campaign, Evans was dropped the next season in favour of the more experienced <a href="Billy%20Trew">Billy Trew</a>, and never represented his country again.
